Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Foundation and Design Framework for Incentives and Efficiency of Mobile Crowd Service Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent advances in smart mobile devices (e.g., smartphones) have enabled many powerful applications and services, fundamentally changing the way we live, work, entertain, and communicate with each other. The project investigates a broad range of emerging and fast-growing smart mobile applications, such as smartphone-based cooperative streaming and data sharing, proximity-based dynamic mobile clouds, mobile device-to-device computing, and opportunistic networking. In those applications, services are provided and consumed by mobile users, through the crowds formed by those users, and through the processing and selling/reselling by service providers and resellers. The project introduces an effective design framework for mobile crowd service (MCS) systems that support those applications. The framework provides mechanisms to incentivize all users and service providers to fairly participate in such systems, which are crucial to the continuing success, wider adoption, and further innovation of smart mobile applications. The outcome of the research will have a significant impact on many aspects of our daily lives that are already permeated by smart mobile devices and applications, and will be integrated with a strong education component including curriculum development, student training, recruiting and engaging underrepresented students.

The project develops a theoretic foundation and design paradigms for developing practical algorithms and architecture that effectively manage the interplay between service providers, resellers, and mobile users in a complete MCS ecosystem. The project first designs a set of dynamic algorithms to incentivize users to truthfully and fairly participate in the proximity-based MCS systems that are formed mainly by dynamic mobile users. For systems where the interaction among all players dominates system dynamics and performance, the project develops an optimization formulation to achieve overall system efficiency and stability. Furthermore, the project investigates scenarios where players might game with the system in order to gain benefit. In a cooperative setting, the project designs a fair revenue sharing mechanism through a cooperative game model of a service provider and its resellers. For the case where all players self-interestedly but rationally game with the system, the project develops a non-cooperative game for static analysis, and a fluid model for dynamic analysis. The research takes into consideration the characteristics of mobile communications, and covers a broad range of MCS systems characterized by their dynamic user mobility patterns, heterogeneous user types and service quality, and distributed and asynchronous computation requirements. This project constitutes a significant advance in the design of mobile networked systems and applications based on smart mobile devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to optimize the performance of the applications that rely on the interconnected crowds formed by mobile users and through the service processing/selling by third parties, e.g., servers at the edge of the Internet. These applications are referred to as Mobile Crowd Service (MCS) applications and the underlying computing systems to support those applications are referred to as MCS systems. Examples of MCS applications include smartphone-based cooperative streaming, proximity-based dynamic mobile clouds, mobile device-to-device computing, and the edge-computing assisted mobile applications. 

We have developed a framework of designing efficient MCS systems and a collection of techniques that can be applied to various MCS applications. The core of the framework includes auction-based incentive mechanisms to address P2P proximity-based MCS (pMCS) systems that are formed by dynamic mobile users which provide and consume services among themselves in a P2P fashion, and a game-theoretic formulation and revenue sharing design to optimize the heterogeneous MCS (hMCS) systems where the interaction among service providers, resellers, and mobile users dominates system dynamics and performance. MCS systems can be regarded as special cases of edge computing paradigm. pMCS corresponds to the extreme edge case where edge servers are hosted on end users? devices; and hMCS corresponds to the case where cloudlets or edge servers sit at cellular base stations or near a city center. 

One major outcome of our auction-based incentive mechanism design is an MobiAuc system that incentivizes mobile users to provide service to other users at the edge. The mechanism addresses users' dynamic mobility patterns through a sequence of correlated auctions including core algorithms such as a Virtual Market algorithm or matching rule and a group matching algorithm. We further extend MoibAuc and develop a DataMart system that determines pricing and buyer-seller matching in distributed fashion without centralized solution that is suitable for highly dynamic and heterogeneous market environment and ad-hoc setting. In addition, a major outcome that addresses hMCS systems is a game-theoretic formulation and marginal-contribution based revenue sharing design to deal with the interaction among edge computing service providers and cloud service providers that offer their computing resources to mobile clients at the edge of the Internet. Our research demonstrates the importance of designing an appropriate revenue sharing mechanism in order to maintain a high system-level efficiency in the face of service providers? self-interested behaviors, and we have shown that the marginal-contribution based revenue sharing mechanisms are crucial to fairness and system performance. 

Besides the aforementioned major outcomes, we have also developed several designs to support various MCS applications. For example, we have developed an integer programming optimal formulation, a novel job-server matching metric, and an efficient heuristic to solve the multi-task and multi-server scheduling problem to achieve ultra-low latency in an MCS system. For stream processing applications, an outcome of our research is an efficient mobile resource aware scheduling algorithm that outperforms other existing algorithms in terms of increased throughput and reduced stream processing delay. A further outcome of our research is a prediction-based task assignment scheme that jointly reduces computation/storage cost, communication cost, and task execution latency by predicting servers? computation capacity in a stochastic environment, which is often the case of mobile users in a pMCS system.

This project contributes to the foundation and design of mobile crowd systems and applications. The outcomes of the project will have a great impact on many aspects of our daily lives that are already permeated by smart mobile devices and applications. The results of this project have been published in several top-tier computer networking conference proceedings and journals. We have also integrated the research with various education activities including developing new curricula, training graduate and undergraduate students in research, and recruiting and engaging under-represented groups of students (i.e., two female PhD students) in our research activities.
